review_title: BAIT AND SWITCH - Don't Trust Job Postings, they won't honor them

cons: If you think that you are going to apply for a job based upon the job title and description, interview based upon that advertised job, accept that advertised job and sign the job description, then actually do the job - THINK AGAIN! They will change everything on you the first day you arrive and if you go to HR and complain, you will be told that is just what we do here at TWU.

review_title: Not a terrible place to work
pros:
My direct supervisor was excellent. I was treated like an intelligent human being and given the space I needed to get the job done and to do it well. Training was a little seat-of-the-pants, but I was given the opportunity to document workflow for subsequent hires, which I have heard worked well since I left. The university (on the staff side) seems to appreciate collaboration. 

The benefits are pretty good, and the employee health initiative is quite nice--there's an incentive to join the university gym, which grants you an extra 30 minutes to your lunch hour each week if you also work out.
cons:
I come at this from a staff point of view: my supervisors were excellent, but the other departments seemed in competition with one another, and there was a looming threat of layoffs and shakeups that made things seem painfully uncertain. 

Despite my degrees in higher education, I was treated as a student worker, and that was beyond frustrating. I tried to connect with my fellow employees and was quite often rebuffed, if not completely ignored. It made for a toxic environment. 

Pay is less than stellar. Obviously the state is suffering in terms of public funding (as it has been and probably will be for some time), and TWU is definitely feeling the crunch.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Denton, TX
pros: Low Pay no benefits no good
cons: Gain experience learn from experts

review_title: Denton, TX: Potential that never came, but is still "in the works."
pros: Family-like orientation to fellow co-workers. Camaraderie among those who are equivalents to your rank. Leave your work on campus when you leave. Offer or consider allowing you to search out training, workshops, conferences to attend to further your learning while on the job.
cons: Higher ups always seemed to say they look out for your well-being in terms of representation, but never saw any movement in terms of progression or salary increase. Not much room for growth. Not much acceptance of "out of the box" ideas. Administration is run by "old blood" and hard to get anything off the ground as far as ideas. However, they have a new Chancellor now as of a few months ago, so hopefully TWU will see some change for the better.

review_title: Texas Woman's University is getting better for both students and employees
pros: TWU is a pretty good place to work depending on why you're here. From my observations, being full time here is hit or miss, and really depends on your boss. However, I was able to glimpse into various facets of the Student Life division as a student, and can say, for the most part, the environment here is great for students and staff alike.
cons: Most of the cons at TWU involve general environment or leadership depending on who you're working for. For students, I've seen both great and really bad situations. Student assistants can be entrusted with more the longer you stay, but it really depends. For full time workers, it is expected you'll make less here than you can in the private sector.

pros: Supervisors that manage your hours are incredibly supportive of your education and will take into account all the other commitments and organizations you are part of. They recognize that you are here for your education first and that your responsibility to your job comes second (within reason, of course). With this in mind, it is also expected that you keep it courteous and professional. It's also very helpful to come into the job as a first year by building connections and networking with peers that are older and more experienced. Incredibly different and more supportive than your roundabout job working retail. My job has also taught me important software skills.
cons: Because we're technically getting paid by the government, that means that the pay is not as flexible and great. However, it is better than working a minimum wage job! As of now (2019), student assistants can only work 20 hours per week, but if you work another part-time job on-campus, you will be able to work something out.

pros: Got your own room.  (They have phased this out in recent years.)  Great people to work with. Awesome leadership experience. Life-long friends.
cons: No support from management; bad compensation for everything that you're doing.  Unruly residents; not enough space in the residence halls. Ridiculous amounts of programs RAs are required to plan.  If residents don't come, it's the RA's fault.

review_title: Excellent work environment. Positive staff members. Great opportunity.
job_title: Student Assistant/Graphic Design Intern in Denton, TX
pros: The staff at Texas Woman's University is very welcoming, friendly, and positive. This university is really understanding of Student Assistants and handles their school and work schedules in a flexible manner. Plus, if you are a student, you don't have to work about commuting to a different work location. My work experience in the Graphics Department really helped me understand the fundamentals of my selected major in graphic design.
cons: The compensation or pay is not the highest. In fact, I believe it's just above minimum wage.

job_title: Associate Director of the Center for Student Development in Denton, TX
pros:
Great people 
Beautiful campus
Very student centered
Campus population and university presence is growing. 
Dr. Feyten is amazing 
Recent cabinet changes have been good for the university
cons:
Change management is very slow
Pay is very low
Work life balance is difficult to maintain
They just changed the logo and mascot of the university and I think this will lose some of the University's history

review_title: Adjunct Instructor - low pay, but lots of autonomy with possibility of benefits
pros: Flexible schedule, autonomy, benefits offered to adjuncts with at least 3 courses- big plus.
cons: Dated processes, not a strong campus community feel, a lot of commuter students, low pay per course ($2500 per course-- less than other DFW area colleges)

review_title: Offers positive working environment and a great team of math and computer science tutors.
job_title: Math and Computer Science Tutor in Denton, TX
pros: Some of the pros of working at the Math and Technology Success Center at Texas Woman's University are: positive working environment, gain experience (by teaching someone else, you are also learning), great team of tutors who are willing to help anytime, the best coordinator and director.
cons: Sometimes the student tutors won't be able to help you, but they will direct you to a faculty who can help you.

pros: The community I've developed with my coworkers is something I value. TWU has a very welcoming environment to new students and staff. I also appreciate having full benefits.
cons: My struggle is with the salary. As an average millennial with student loans, car payment, etc., I live paycheck to paycheck.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Benbrook, TX
pros: Ability to work with students and staff in a professional setting. Exposure to a complex technology driven department. "On the cutting edge of online teaching."
cons: Heavy work overload (4 online professors assistant and 20 hour work at campus) with little regard to student's scheduling.

pros: Loved working for TWU most of the time but like anyplace it has it's quirks.  The people are fantastic and I felt like they really cared about our students and the mission of the University.
cons: Too much Red-tape and lengthy decision times in getting things done.

pros: Flexible hours, ability to work and go to class, very good facilities, easy to get around campus, easy to find parking
cons: Management micromanages, not a lot of office space, limited in the amount of resources available, facilities have to be shared among classes and athletics

pros: Your administration is available to you around the clock, and you can almost always find someone to talk to. Payment is quick and direct, however only once a month.
cons: Response time can be very slow with administration, and departments do not effectively work well together (Financial Aid and Registrar)

pros: State of Texas benefits are nice, but what's the point when the office you're in won't even let you use sick leave to see a specialist that you need to see quarterly?
cons: Low pay (made 6k more at another university for the exact same kind of work).  The infighting and backstabbing at this university makes it clear that if you're not part of the "in crowd" then you will be run out.  Two of the  women I had to work with were absolutely awful and refused to allow me into the team.  They both are extremely condescending and will throw people under the bus for anything that implicates they made a mistake.  They will happily have non-professional shout outs with you in front of students that you're supposed to manage and do everything they can to emaciate any kind of leadership role your job requires.   Work/Life balance is a joke there.  Due to some of my personal medical conditions I have to see doctors regularly.  It was a nightmare just to schedule my quarterly rheumatologist appointments.  More than once I was asked if this was even necessary!  To top it off, I had to deal with a five and a half hour texting battle with one of my co-workers when we were off work because she felt it necessary to tell me I lacked certain basic skills.  Obviously I quit working there.  No amount of money nor time off was worth the stress and hassle of working there.  It reached a point to where they would yell at me for not telling them I was going to the bathroom.  Straight up hostile work environment.  If you want to work in higher education find another university.  I reached out to Human Resources there and received no help at all.  In my exit interview I submitted the journal I was keeping of these incidents.  As far as I can tell nothing was done.

review_title: Wonderful growth opportunity, outstanding colleagues and mission.
